newsitem.title: JAPAN: Japan should not raise rates - opposition politician.
newsitem.headline: Japan should not raise rates - opposition politician.

text.p: Japan should not raise interest rates this year, as such a move could harm Japan's economy and financial institutions, a key Lower House member from the opposition New Frontier Party (Shinshinto) told Reuters Financial Television on Wednesday.

"An interest rate hike now would put a further brake on the economy. It would also be a considerable blow to financial institutions suffering from bad debts," said Yoshio Suzuki, who is also a former executive director of the Bank of Japan (BOJ).
"I understand that some people wish to see a rise in interest rates, but Japan is not on a firm recovery trend. A rate hike would result in the economy quickly losing speed," Suzuki said.
Higher interest rates could also aggravate Japan's financial crisis, Suzuki said.
"Under such circumstances, a hike in interest rates is unthinkable," he said.
Suzuki also said Japanese financial institutions' bad loan writeoffs were far from over.
"The figures for bad loans compiled by the Ministry of Finance may be showing a decline, but land prices are continuing to fall," Suzuki said.
"A decline in the value of collateral means that loans that are recoverable now may eventually turn into unrecoverable loans. So it is doubtful whether bad loans are actually decreasing," he added.
